title: Change Analytics
content:
Service Management's Change Analytics feature offers insights based on the available data, and suggestions for improvements in change management. It displays a graphical analysis of change management KPI performance. In addition, you can filter the service, the changes, and the time to sharpen your analysis. 

Note Change Analytics doesn't include retroactive changes when generating reports.

How to access Change Analytics

To access Change Analytics, from the main menu, select Build > Change > Analytics.

Change Analytics User Interface (UI)

The Change Analytics UI includes the following elements.

Filter panel

Click the Filter button to display the following options.

Filter option Description
Time range: Allows you to select the time range the analysis is to include.
Include only changes:

Allows you to select changes to be included in the analysis according to:

  • Category
  • Reason for change

For example, select Facilities as the category, and Legislation as the reason for change.
Filter services by: Allows you to further filter the selection of changes the analysis is to include. You can filter changes by fields of the affected service.

Services bar

The services bar allows you to select different services for analysis.

Services bar option Description
Overview All services matching the current filter. Referred to as overview mode.
Most changed services A list of the services with the highest number of changes affecting them.
Select a service A drop-down list allowing you to select a service.

Success rate panel

This panel displays the percentage of successful changes out of the selected changes. For KPI calculation purposes, a change is successful if it has a completion code of either Successful or Successful with problems, and has no incident related to it. 

Note

  • Service Management only displays insights and suggested action points when the number of successful and unsuccessful changes within your selection exceeds a minimum threshold.
  • Change Analytics results are calculated on a daily basis. They aren't real-time statistics.
UI Description
Point to the icon to display Help content.
Click to configure the KPI settings for this panel. For more information, see Configure KPI settings for Change Analytics.

Click to display a line chart showing the success rate trends within the past 6 months.

Note  

  • You can select the horizontal axis to show either weeks or months. The chart automatically switches to the weekly view if the available data is all within the same calendar month.
  • For the line chart to display, there must be data in at least two weeks so as to show a trend between two points.
  • You can point to a marked data point to see:
    • The KPI value at that time
    • The delta in the KPI value compared to the preceding data point
    • The relevant time range
  • All
  • Standard
  • Normal
  • Emergency
 Click to display the information for all changes, or each of the types of change.
INSIGHTS This part of the panel displays a short observation about the success rate. You may see a message highlighting the percentage improvement needed to reach the goal.
HOW CAN YOU IMPROVE?

This part of the panel displays potential ways of improving the success rate.

Guidance

You might see a message giving you guidance about which services to improve to move the success rate KPI towards the goal. To do this, Service Management looks at the total number of changes affecting the different services as well as the number of unsuccessful changes and how these unsuccessful changes influence the overall success rate.

Action points

Click view suggested action points:

  1. To display comparisons of successful and unsuccessful changes with suggested action points as tooltips when you point to the icon . The comparisons are based on these change characteristics:

    • A build and test plan

      The use of a build and test plan allows for a deployment package to be built and tested before actual implementation. You may increase the success rate by greater use of build and test plans.

    • Involved CIs

      Associating changes with involved CIs helps impact analysis, collision detection, and speeds up incident root cause analysis. You may increase the success rate by associating more changes with their involved CIs.

    • An execution task plan

      Use of an execution task plan helps minimize errors by setting prescribed and robust procedures. You may increase the success rate by developing execution task plans in changes, and particularly in change models.

  2. To display the one or two most frequently used models responsible for unsuccessful changes.

  3. If a service isn't already modeled, you may also see a suggestion to model it in SACM. For more information, see Actual services.

    Note This suggestion may be displayed only when viewing a specific service, and not overview mode.

Standard changes panel

This panel displays the percentage of standard changes out of the selected changes.

Note

  • Service Management only displays insights and suggested action points when the number of standard and normal changes within your selection exceeds a minimum threshold.
  • Change Analytics results are calculated on a daily basis. They aren't real-time statistics.
UI Description
Point to the icon to display Help content.
Click to configure the KPI settings for this panel. For more information, see Configure KPI settings for Change Analytics.

Click to display a line chart showing the standard changes trends within the past 6 months.

Note  

  • You can select the horizontal axis to show either weeks or months. The chart automatically switches to the weekly view if the available data is all within the same calendar month.
  • For the line chart to display, there must be data in at least two weeks so as to show a trend between two points.
  • You can point to a marked data point to see:
    • The KPI value at that time
    • The delta in the KPI value compared to the preceding data point
    • The relevant time range
INSIGHTS

This part of the panel displays short observations about standard changes. You may see messages about:

  • The difference in implementation time between standard and normal changes.
  • The difference in success rate between standard and non-standard changes.
HOW CAN YOU IMPROVE? This part of the panel displays potential ways of improving the standard changes KPI. You may see a message suggesting one or more normal change models as possible candidates suitable for conversion to a standard change model. To make this suggestion, Service Management looks at the models of changes which conform most closely to these parameters: low impact, low risk, and high rate of success.

Change automation panel

This panel displays the percentage of changes with automated tasks in their execution plan, out of the selected changes. For KPI calculation purposes, an automated change is a change that has at least one automated task in its execution plan. Not all tasks require to be automated.

Note

  • Service Management only displays insights and suggested action points when the number of manual and automated changes within your selection exceeds a minimum threshold.
  • Change Analytics results are calculated on a daily basis. They aren't real-time statistics.
UI Description
Point to the icon to display Help content.
Click to configure the KPI settings for this panel. For more information, see Configure KPI settings for Change Analytics.

Click to display a line chart showing the change automation trends within the past 6 months.

Note  

  • You can select the horizontal axis to show either weeks or months. The chart automatically switches to the weekly view if the available data is all within the same calendar month.
  • For the line chart to display, there must be data in at least two weeks so as to show a trend between two points.
  • You can point to a marked data point to see:
    • The KPI value at that time
    • The delta in the KPI value compared to the preceding data point
    • The relevant time range
  • All
  • Standard
  • Normal
 Click to display the information for all changes, or each of the types of change.
INSIGHTS

This part of the panel displays short observations about automated changes. You might see messages about:

  • The difference in success rate between automated and non-automated changes.
  • The percentage of fully automated changes out of all automated changes.
  • The average duration of manual changes. This may point at potential manual labor savings to be made by automating the change.
HOW CAN YOU IMPROVE?

This part of the panel displays potential ways of improving the change automation KPI. You might see a message suggesting one or more change models may be suitable for adding automation. To make this suggestion, Service Management looks at the models of standard changes (with and without a task plan) and normal changes with a task plan.

Configure KPI settings for Change Analytics

Note You must have the appropriate permissions to be able to configure the KPI settings.

You can configure the KPI settings for each Change Analytics panel.

  1. From the main menu, select Build > Change > Analytics.

  2. Click on the panel you want to configure. The Configure KPI settings dialog box is displayed.

  3. Type the values you want for the following fields:

    Field Description
    Red range

    The lowest range of results displayed.

    • The value of this field sets the top of the red range.

    • The bottom of the range is always 0%.
    Yellow range The middle range of results displayed. The values here set the top and bottom of the yellow range.
    Green range

    The highest range of results displayed.

    • The value of this field sets the bottom of the green range.

    • The top of the range is always 100%.
    Set goal at

    The percentage goal. The goal displays on the dashboard panel as an icon:

Understanding and working with the Change Analytics reports

Success rate

This KPI is calculated as described in its Help Information pop-up:

The formula:

Success rate = (Successful Changes ) ⁄ (Closed Changes)

Where the Successful Changes are the changes that have a completion code of ‘Successful’ or ‘Successful with problems’ and have no incidents related to them; the Closed Changes are the selected changes (All, Standard, Normal, or Emergency) that have a completion code and CloseTime.

Improvement needed = (Goal rate) - (Success rate)

In essence:

  • Analytic queries tally the ratio of Changes that were successful based on their Completion Code, and these are further filtered to take into account Changes that might have been closed as Successful but later proved to have issues resulting in the raising of an Incident Caused by Change.
  • The KPI can be shown against different types of Changes, and this is enabled by basic subsequent filtering on the data.
  • In terms of ‘How to Improve’, we look at all the changes that were not successful, and filter to the top two types of unsuccessful changes as grouped by the change associated Services. This helps the Change Analyst by showing where to best invest time in improvement. Of course, the ultimate goal is to have all changes be successful, but here we show where the effort of improvement should be paid first.
  • Having identified where improvement should be made, the Analytics can then be used to understand how to make improvements in the most effective manner, as shown below:
  • On the left column, the Analyst can see what characterizes unsuccessful changes. For example, we query to compare the ratios of failure or success when taking into account Good Practices in Change management such as:
    • Proper planning (i.e. Having Build and Test plans defined in the Change)
    • Explicitly locating and associating the list of Involved CIs
    • Detailed planning in a Task Plan
  • By looking at these suggestions, the Analyst can learn that the most effective action to improve success may be to start by requiring that all changes have a Build and Test Plan.
  • These recommendations also query to find the group of Change Models that most heavily account for failures. The Analyst may choose to start the improvement work in those models.

Standard changes

The formula:

Standard changes percentage = (Standard Changes) ⁄ (Total Changes)

Where the Total Changes = (Standard Changes) + (Normal changes) + (Emergency Changes). Note that the changes should be closed and have completion code.

  • This KPI helps to analyze the impact to Implementation Time and Success Rates based on the practice of using Standard vs. Normal changes, as described in the Informational Help:
  • The conversion of a change into becoming Standard requires effort by the Change Analyst, and these KPIs help guide where the effort would have the most value
  • The insights show the savings in Implementation time, calculated by the total duration that the Change spent from planning to closure.
    That is, Implementation time = Change Close Time - Change Create Time
  • The insights also show Success comparison, based on the same criteria of Success described above.
    Where the Success comparison rate = (Successful Standard Changes)/(Total Standard Changes) - (Successful Normal Changes + Successful Emergency Changes)/(Total Normal Changes + Total Emergency Changes)
  • Finally, knowing the value of taking the effort to standardize some of the Change processes, the analytics shows where to start the work by listing the two types of changes that would render the largest gain, as grouped by the associated change models. Improving those models and using them in standard change implementation can provide the best gains in time savings and success.

Change automation

  • This final KPI is associated with the practice of automating a change implementation, with automation defined as shown in the Information Help on the analytic:
  • In practice, Automation Tasks can be quite effective in making a number of actions. This is especially true when the Automation is combined with invocation of Operation Orchestration flows.
  • The effort to automate a change needs to be taken into account as not all changes can be automated without it. The Analytic report aims to show where to spend the effort by showing where there is the most value to be gained.
  • First, the report analyzes automated and non-automated to provide comparative value of automation as it relates to:
    • Improvement of Success (as defined above)
    • Savings in implementation time (as defined above)
  • As with the other KPIs, having identified the value, the Analytics also provides guidance to where to spend the effort of defining automations based on the top three Change Models that stand to gain the most Time Savings through the introduction of automation.
